description:
This will be a minor effect relative to line-of-sight velocity, but it is an effect at relativistic velocities.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redshift

UPDATE1:  I redid the bulk of this PR due to the suggestions from @brittonsmith , as he was right that my original attempts at accounting for transverse doppler redshift were misguided and overly complicated.  The current change implements a single doppler redshift due to the combined effects of the transverse and radial velocity components.  I have tested this internally, and it results in a very very small effect at most low-z low-velocity datasets, but it gives the correct results with a dataset with relativistic speeds.  An accompanying PR will add tests and documentation to the LightRay class.

UPDATE2: This updates the `get_los_velocity` kwarg in the `LightRay` class to `use_peculiar_velocity`, since that is more accurate now.  This is also the same name as the equivalent kwarg in the `AbsorptionSpectrum` class.  Yes, it is a minor change in API, but it is a kwarg that is True by default so I don't know how many people are setting it by hand.

UPDATE3: Including deprecation warning for `get_los_velocity` kwarg.

UPDATE4: Bug fix.  After extensive discussions and derivations, it is clear that we had an additional 1+z term normalizing the doppler redshift component (ostensibly to convert it from physical units to comoving units).  It was determined that this is incorrect, and I have removed this normalization.  I cited the appropriate source material in the code comments.  I have tested this and it gives appropriate values.  I also added a "redshift_dopp" field to the LightRay output representing the doppler redshift alone.
title: Adds effects of transverse doppler redshift to LightRay

pullrequest.title: Adds effects of transverse doppler redshift to LightRay

content.raw:
I'm not sure this is correct.  It looks like you're calculating separate redshifts for the line of sight and transverse velocity components.  I think you need to be implementing the following formula:

![b517c27421d431760320f1474d01be52.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/194264166-b517c27421d431760320f1474d01be52.png)
(taken from wikipedia),

where Theta is the angle between the line of sight vector and the velocity vector.  This should give you a single redshift component for peculiar motion.
content.html:
I'm not sure this is correct. It looks like you're calculating separate redshifts for the line of sight and transverse velocity components. I think you need to be implementing the following formula:

(taken from wikipedia),

where Theta is the angle between the line of sight vector and the velocity vector. This should give you a single redshift component for peculiar motion.

pullrequest.title: Adds effects of transverse doppler redshift to LightRay

content.raw: I believe that adding two orthogonal components is equivalent to the above.  And it's easier to do this way, since we are already calculating the line of sight velocity, so we just get the transverse velocity and calculate its corresponding redshift, rather than figuring out theta and throwing out the LOS component.  Lastly, in the absorption spectrum analysis module, it already uses the line of sight velocity in the voigt profile function, as opposed to accounting for this theta component.  Not sure what to do on that front.
content.html: I believe that adding two orthogonal components is equivalent to the above. And it's easier to do this way, since we are already calculating the line of sight velocity, so we just get the transverse velocity and calculate its corresponding redshift, rather than figuring out theta and throwing out the LOS component. Lastly, in the absorption spectrum analysis module, it already uses the line of sight velocity in the voigt profile function, as opposed to accounting for this theta component. Not sure what to do on that front.

pullrequest.title: Adds effects of transverse doppler redshift to LightRay

content.raw: I'm going to need to prove to myself that these two approaches are equivalent.  On the second point, didn't you change the absorption spectrum so that it now uses the "redshift_eff" field, which is what we're calculating here?
content.html: I'm going to need to prove to myself that these two approaches are equivalent. On the second point, didn't you change the absorption spectrum so that it now uses the "redshift_eff" field, which is what we're calculating here?

pullrequest.title: Adds effects of transverse doppler redshift to LightRay

content.raw:
I'll do some calculations and demonstrate that the two forms are equivalent (or maybe prove that they're not!).  I'll follow up on this later today.

As for the absorption spectrum stuff, yes and no.  Yes, it uses the redshift_eff field to calculate the wavelength offset for the observed line, but the velocity_los field is *also* passed into the actual voigt line profile code, and i haven't investigated what it does in there, since that code is somewhat dark and mysterious.
content.html:
I'll do some calculations and demonstrate that the two forms are equivalent (or maybe prove that they're not!). I'll follow up on this later today.

As for the absorption spectrum stuff, yes and no. Yes, it uses the redshift_eff field to calculate the wavelength offset for the observed line, but the velocity_los field is also passed into the actual voigt line profile code, and i haven't investigated what it does in there, since that code is somewhat dark and mysterious.

pullrequest.title: Adds effects of transverse doppler redshift to LightRay

content.raw: I'm sorry you find my code dark and mysterious.  The line of sight velocity is not used in there.  The voigt profile generation only requires the doppler width of the line, which comes solely from the temperature, and shift of the line, which now comes entirely from the redshift_eff field.  The only place that the line of sight velocity is referred to at all is where it is printed out with each line component that is laid down, which is non-essential.  We can still write out the line of sight velocity for that, but it isn't needed elsewhere.
content.html: I'm sorry you find my code dark and mysterious. The line of sight velocity is not used in there. The voigt profile generation only requires the doppler width of the line, which comes solely from the temperature, and shift of the line, which now comes entirely from the redshift_eff field. The only place that the line of sight velocity is referred to at all is where it is printed out with each line component that is laid down, which is non-essential. We can still write out the line of sight velocity for that, but it isn't needed elsewhere.

pullrequest.title: Adds effects of transverse doppler redshift to LightRay

content.raw:
I think everyone can agree that the `voigt_old()` that Charles gave us from some IDL code *is* dark and mysterious, so this was certainly not meant as a dig at you:

https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/src/c2ce64029b634223fc234dd68037d07a19c02687/yt/analysis_modules/absorption_spectrum/absorption_line.py?at=yt&fileviewer=file-view-default

That said, you're correct that the line of sight velocity is not used there--I stand corrected.  So I guess this means that the worries about the velocity_los being used elsewhere in the code to calculate redshifts are moot.  That's great!
content.html:
I think everyone can agree that the voigt_old() that Charles gave us from some IDL code is dark and mysterious, so this was certainly not meant as a dig at you:

https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/src/c2ce64029b634223fc234dd68037d07a19c02687/yt/analysis_modules/absorption_spectrum/absorption_line.py?at=yt&fileviewer=file-view-default

That said, you're correct that the line of sight velocity is not used there--I stand corrected. So I guess this means that the worries about the velocity_los being used elsewhere in the code to calculate redshifts are moot. That's great!

content.raw: This was done in order to avoid the -1 on the line of sight velocity, and to further propagate the reversal in radial velocity to the theta term.

pullrequest.title: Adds effects of transverse doppler redshift to LightRay

content.raw: Having seen the majority of the discussions that went into this and based on my own understanding of the velocity terms and corresponding derivation for calculating the redshift due to peculiar velocity, I'm currently convinced that this is all correct.  I think this should definitely get merged in to ensure that our redshift calculations are accurate.
content.html: Having seen the majority of the discussions that went into this and based on my own understanding of the velocity terms and corresponding derivation for calculating the redshift due to peculiar velocity, I'm currently convinced that this is all correct. I think this should definitely get merged in to ensure that our redshift calculations are accurate.
